Award.AwardTitle: Evolutionary genetics of adaptation in natural populations of Arabidopsis thaliana
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding how organisms adapt to the many challenges they experience in nature is a central goal in biology. Knowledge of the genetic mechanisms underlying adaptation in nature is also useful for increasing crop yields and for the conservation of wild species. One such challenge faced by organisms at high latitudes is freezing temperatures. This research investigates the genetics of freezing tolerance in the mouse-eared cress, a relative of many crop species that has become a "model" organism for which many genetic tools have been developed. In earlier work, the researchers collected seeds of this species from Italy and Sweden and planted them in experimental gardens located in each country. They found that freezing tolerance is required to survive the long, cold winters in Sweden, whereas freezing tolerance reduces performance in Italy. This result exemplifies the concept of biological "trade-offs"; adaptation to one environment often reduces performance elsewhere. This simple principle can explain why there are so many different species on earth, in that each species is adapted to a particular environment. The research investigates the genetic control of freezing tolerance and explores the mechanisms that contribute to the tradeoff in performance across environments. The genetic mechanisms identified in these studies may be useful tools for producing new crop varieties with increased yield in cold climates. In addition, the research team will perform outreach activities that advance scientific literacy and promote careers in science. Michigan State University scientists will contribute to a partnership between K-12 teachers and the W.K. Kellogg Biological Station to develop lesson plans that support Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) for inquiry based learning.

The research employs cutting edge genetic technologies to address the mechanisms and adaptive value of freezing tolerance using three complementary approaches. First, the genetic basis of freezing tolerance will be further examined in the two original populations in Sweden and Italy using new lines manipulating freezing tolerance genes in otherwise homogeneous parental backgrounds. These lines will then be grown in controlled environment chambers and in the field to estimate the importance of freezing tolerance genes for genetic trade-offs in performance across environments. Second, the genetic basis of freezing tolerance will be investigated in
four new populations from Scandinavia and Spain with dramatic differences in freezing tolerance. Third, this research will be expanded to an even broader scale, asking if the same genes for freezing tolerance found in these focal populations are found in other geographic regions. The techniques employed in part three are similar to those used to study the genetics of many human diseases. Taken together, these studies examine the genetic basis of freezing tolerance in a broad diversity of natural populations and assess the mechanisms of performance trade-offs for this important adaptive trait.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Scientists, farmers, and gardeners have long recognized that certain varieties of plants grow best in particular climates. For example, plant populations from very cold climates often do not do well in warm climates, and vice versa. Understanding the traits (physical and cellular level characteristics) of plants, and the genetic makeup determining those traits, that allow plants to adapt to their local environments has been major goal of plant science in the last century. Many big questions remain unanswered, including: What are the traits and genes that contribute to adaptation? Does adaptation to one environment reduce performance in other environments? To answer these questions, a research team led by Assistant Professor Christopher Oakley at Purdue University and working in collaboration with Professor Jon Ågren from Uppsala University (Sweden) have investigated the role of freezing tolerance in adaptation in the Mouse-eared cress, a widely distributed model plant species.

         This work builds on previous research focusing on two natural populations of this species, one from Sweden near the northern limit of the native range, and the other from Italy near the southern range limit in Eurasia. Using what is called a reciprocal transplant experiment (planting both types at both locations in the field), it was demonstrated that local genotypes outperform foreign genotypes. This “home field advantage”, also known as local adaptation, is driven in part by the ability to withstand the very cold winters in Sweden. Interestingly, the ability to withstand cold winters requires cool fall temperatures that give the plants the signal that winter is coming. Plants in Italy get these cool temperature signals as well, so preparation for winter may the reason why plants from Sweden perform poorly there (imagine the discomfort of wearing a down parka on a warm sunny spring day in Italy). Finally this work has identified regions of the genome that have large effects of freezing tolerance also affect local adaptation in the field. Current and ongoing work has several primary goals. The first goal was to determine the effects of genomic regions on freezing tolerance and local adaptation, both individually and in combination. The second goal was to determine the genes underlying these genomic regions. The final two goals related to broadening the understanding of these genes, freezing tolerance, and local adaptation across the range of the species. 

         Outcomes of this work include scientific publications, accrual of large datasets, and production of unique genetic materials. Genetic resources include a panel of 40 near isogenic lines. Each of these lines contains a small portion of one parental genome crossed into the opposite genome, allowing the precise examination of how small genomic changes influence freezing tolerance and field performance. These lines have been used in growth chamber experiment and planted in the field sites for four consecutive years. Additional advanced lines contain multiple genomic segments, enabling experiments to evaluate the extent to which the effect of one genomic region depends on the genotype elsewhere in the genome. These combined lines have been planted in the field sites for two consecutive years. One primary result is the identification of key players in a major gene pathway involved in freezing tolerance, and ongoing experiments to determine the roles of individual players in performance in each environment. One of the genomic regions controlling large differences in freezing tolerance between Italy and Sweden is a single gene that regulates how many other genes work in response to cold temperatures. By manipulating this single gene (using gene editing approaches) and looking at patterns of how genes are turned off or on across the entire genome in response to cold temperatures, it was determined which genes were most important in plants respones to cold temperatures. Ongoing experiments will determine the consequences of these genes for local adaptation. Additional genetic resources developed include a new genetic mapping population from a cross between a low elevation (sea level) and a high elevation (12,000 ft above sea level) population from Spain, which will provide an opportunity to investigate if the same genes underly differences in freezing tolerance along different ecological gradient in temperature. Additionally, complete genomic sequence was generated for 384 lines from 48 population which will allow complementary approaches to identifying the genes underlying freezing tolerance and local adaptation

         With increasing climatic variability it is more important than ever to understand the genes and traits that govern plant responses to the environment. Understanding the genomic basis of plant responses to the temperature may help us to engineer increased resiliency of agricultural species in the face of climate variability. Although the climate is generally warming, increasing variability will mean that some plants might not get the sufficient signal to prepare for winter. This loss of an ability prepare for winter at the molecular level could have negative consequences for both natural populations and agriculture.
